subject: How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: Can anyone point me towards a book that give some practical insights into the thinking process a programmer goes through to write a good set of tests? Thanks
messageBody:
Can anyone point me towards a book that give some practical insights into
the thinking process a programmer goes through to write a good set of
tests?

Thanks

lee



On Tue, 21 Jan 2003 11:41:47 +0900 (JST), Curt Sampson <yahoo_sucks@...>
wrote:

> <html><body>
>
>
> <tt>
> On Mon, 20 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:<BR>
> <BR>
> > Generally speaking, you don't really know these things until you
> write<BR>
> > test code, which is really just sample client code, look at it,<BR>
> > evaluate it and move on. In general, it is when one sees it "in
> print"<BR>
> > than one really looks at it carefully. Writing the test first<BR>
> > guarantees this, while writing the stub first does not.<BR>
> <BR>
> Actually, another point I forgot to mention is that writing the
> testing<BR>
> code first gets you writing testable code faster. I know that when
> I'm<BR>
> writing unit tests for legacy code, I frequently have to change the<BR>
> design of the code so I can test it more easily.<BR>
> <BR>
> cjs<BR>
